casebody.data:
The Shaped Seamless Stocking Co., Plaintiff, v. The Snow Church Co., Respondent. (City Court of New York,

General Term,

February, 1897.) 1. Parties — Receiver of corporation. A receiver of a corporation appointed in an action by a judgment creditor for the sequestration of its property is not entitled as of right to be substituted, as plaintiff in an action brought by the corporation prior to his appointment, but such substitution is discretionary with the court. 2. Same — Substitution. Such substitution may properly be refused where it appears that the defendant in the action has been instrumental, in having the receiver appointed, and that the plaintiff’s attorney has a greater interest in the recovery than the plaintiff has. Appeal by the receiver of the plaintiff from an order denying his motion to be substituted as plaintiff and to' amend the complaint by setting up his appointment. Thomas Dilleran, for appellant. James Flynn, for respondent. Van Wyck, Ch. J.

The appeal is from an order denying the receiver’s motion to be substituted as plaintiff herein and to amend the complaint by setting up his appointment, since the commencement of this action, in an action, not by the attorney-general on *422behalf of the People for the dissolution of the corporation, but by a judgment creditor for the sequestration of its property. The appointment of a receiver of a corporation or of its property does not work its dissolution, nor prevent, it from joining in litigation' affecting its indebtedness and being bound by an adjudication therein. However, it is otherwise of dissolution, for, after judgment dissolving a corporation and appointing a receiver, an action cannot be commenced against it by service of process on an officer. The record in this case does not show dissolution, and the receiver’s application to be substituted as plaintiff comes within the provisions of section 756 of the Code, under which an order of substitution is usually granted, but it is discretionary, and the court may withhold it. Here the.withholding of the order was a proper exercise of this discretionary power of the court, for the uncontradicted proof shows that the plaintiff’s attorney has a much larger money interest in the recovery than the plaintiff or its receiver, and tends to show that the attorney for defendant herein was instrumental in having the receiver appointed of the property of the plaintiff herein, and, although this may in no way influence the action of the receiver, still it indicates such an interference by defendant in the affairs of the plaintiff as may be injurious to plaintiff’s casse at the trial, and especially as plaintiff’s attorney has a greater interest in the recovery, than plaintiff.

Order affirmed, with costs.

O’Dwyer, J., concurs. ■

Order affirmed, with costs.
